title: lodash eval/new Function() usage causing Next.js Middleware to fail

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Next.js middleware runs on a [strict runtime](https://nextjs.org/docs/api-reference/edge-runtime), which does not allow `eval` or `new Function(evalString)`:

>The following JavaScript language features are disabled, and will not work:
>    [eval](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/eval): Evaluates JavaScript code represented as a string
>    [new Function(evalString)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Global_Objects/Function): Creates a new function with the code provided as an argument

Can Lodash still run in this environment? For example `trim` imports `_root.js` which uses this type of logic for a global object reference:

```js
/** Used as a reference to the global object. */
var root = freeGlobal || freeSelf || Function('return this')();
```

This results in the following Next.js error during build:

```
Failed to compile.

../../../node_modules/lodash/_root.js
Dynamic Code Evaluation (e. g. 'eval', 'new Function') not allowed in Middleware pages/_middleware

Import trace for requested module:
../../../node_modules/lodash/_Symbol.js
../../../node_modules/lodash/_baseToString.js
../../../node_modules/lodash/trim.js
./src/pages/_middleware.tsx
```

In regards to issue https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/3328, it seems like this behavior is avoidable. Is this still the case?

title: `includes(collection, target)` doesn't throw typescript error when `target` is not part of union type `collection`

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This
```typescript
includes(['BLA', 'BLUBB'] as ('BLA' | 'BLUBB')[], 'Another item that is not in the collection and should be highlighted red by TypeScript')
```
works as `includes` actually **extends** the union type array passed as the first argument (why?).

This on the other hand
```typescript
(['BLA', 'BLUBB'] as ('BLA' | 'BLUBB')[]).includes('Another item that is not in the collection and should be highlighted red by TypeScript')
```
fails (as expected) with the Typescript error 
`TS2345: Argument of type '"Another item that is not in the collection and should be highlighted red by TypeScript"' is not assignable to parameter of type '"BLA" | "BLUBB"'.`

title: Add dropEndsWhile

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello everyone,

This adds a `dropEndsWhile` function that drops elements from both ends of the array. I simply modeled it after the existing functions and it just calls `baseWhile` twice. I also did attempt to rewrite `baseWhile` to take an extra argument (`fromLeft`) which would change the new function so it would only need to call `baseWhile` once. However, it doesn't appear that `npm run test` actually tests these array functions, and I couldn't figure out how to actually run these tests, so I decided to stop and instead proceed to open this PR and to ask for assistance on that.

Please let me know how to run the tests so that I can finish up the PR.

Thanks!

title: Missing isRange method on API
body:
Hi,
I've just discovered that isRange is undefined while should be a function.

**Steps to reproduce**
```
Go to lodash.com and run devTools in console mode

When enter in inspect tool's console: _
Then see _ function

When enter in console: _.range
Then see range function

When enter in console: _.isRange
[FAILURE] Then see isRange function
```
Last expectation fails.
isRange is undefined while should be _.inRange(number, [start=0], end) https://lodash.com/docs/4.17.15#inRange

Best regards,
Jakub

title: Lodash FP Documentation

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
It's great that there's a [Lodash FP Guide](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/FP-Guide) that helps understand how to use this library in an FP flow. However, we still need to mentally derive how to use the functions (how many arguments am I capped to, what's the arity, which functions are exceptions to the reversed arguments rule or have a custom ordering of arguments, etc.) instead of looking at a definitive truth per function.

Are we able to do one of:

1. Generate documentation like the original documentation but for FP
2. Have a section per function in the current documentation that calls out the FP argument ordering
3. The wiki, instead of (or along with) listing how to derive the arguments for the functions, just list out all the functions with their arguments. It could link to the original documentation.

I'm constantly using the functions incorrectly and having to figure out if I'm determining the arguments correctly or if it fits under an exception.

title: Please reduce NPM package size with the "files" option

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello,
I've been trying to reduce the size of my project's dependencies, and I noticed that lodash takes up a huge amount of space in node_modules: 4.8 megabytes, to be exact. This is entirely unneeded, however, as you already build your entire script into an all-encompassing minified form of lodash.min.js. If you used the `files` parameter in your package.json, the _entirety_ of your package could take up 74 kb (72 kb for lodash.min.js and 2 kb for package.json. I would greatly appreciate it if you did this. You've already done 99% of the work, so I think the only thing you have to do is add `"files": ["lodash.min.js"]` and change `"main": "lodash.js"` to `"main": "lodash.min.js"`. As Lodash is used by literally over a hundred thousand packages, this would have an enormously beneficial impact on the entire community of Node.JS users. (Note that this benefit would be multiplied in the case where different dependencies use different release versions of lodash.)

If you're worried that packages somehow might need all the extra scripts, perhaps you can release a `lodash-complete` package which includes all the source files... but I don't think that would be necessary. After all, if someone wants all the lodash source files, they can just get them from this GitHub repo.

Thank you for your consideration.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/11487870/151673103-771ca39e-dd8d-4bea-b5ed-cbf6163ac372.png)

title: Feature Request: `amend` family

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Something I think would be nice to have, keeping in the spirit of functional programming, is a way to update lists non-destructively.

For this I propose the `amend` family of functions, which take a collection, position or criteria, and returns an updated collection, which leaves the original untouched.
```js
const a = _.range(6);
const b = _.amend(a, 2, 'X');

console.log(a); // prints [0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
console.log(b); // prints [0, 1, "X", 3, 4, 5]
```
This could possibly also work on strings, which are already immutable:
```js
const c = 'bat';
const d = _.amend(c, 0, 'c');

console.log(c); // prints "cat"
```
Furthermore, an `amendMany` could be used to update multiple values at once:
```js
const d = _.range(6);
const e = _.amendMany(d, [0, 2, 4], 'xyz')

console.log(e); // prints ["x", 1, "y", 3, "z", 5]
```
And lastly an `amendWhen`:
```js
const f = [1, 2, 3, 0, 7, 1];
const g = _.amendWhen(f, (x) => x > 2, (x) => -x);

console.log(g); // prints [1, 2, -3, 0, -7, 1]
```
Admitedly, `amendWhen` is less useful, as it can be achieved with some clever application of mapping and reduction, but it's sill nice and straightforward

title: pack and unpack to switch from function taking array of argumento to variadic function and viceversa
body:
I've just been wandering why lodash/fp doesn't have these two functions:
```
unpack = f => x => f(...x)
pack = f => (...x) => f(x)
```
I'm borrowing the name from the function [`boost::hana::unpack`](http://boostorg.github.io/hana/group__group-_foldable.html#ga7b0c23944364ce61136e10b978ae2170) provided by the C++ library [Boost.Hana](http://boostorg.github.io/hana/).

In my C++ programming experience, I've used `unpack` a gazillion times, so I was wandering how comes nobody needs it in JavaScript.

Or maybe Lodash has such a function and I just can't guess the name?

title: !isEmpty will tell Typescript that the variable is safely not empty
body:
Hello,
I got this real issue and I think other might have too, so I share it here.

original issue: https://github.com/DefinitelyTyped/DefinitelyTyped/issues/45521

so like the explanation, typescript wont recognize isEmpty invocation result, and it will resulting the variable still has `undefined` type, and currently to fix this is with `non-asserting` like `someobj.somevar!`

my proposal is to modify the isEmpty types like:
```
isEmpty<T>(value:` T | undefined) : value is undefined
```

I hope it might help.
Best Regards!

`let name = 'my-engine:my-engine/$site';`
`_.trimEnd(name, '/$site');`

Actual output - `my-engine:my-engin`

Actual output - `my-engine:my-engines1`
Expected output - `my-engine:my-engines1`

Eg- 3
`let name = 'my-engine:my-engines/$site';`
`_.trimEnd(name, '/$site');`

Actual output - `my-engine:my-engin`
Expected output - `my-engine:my-engines`

Please let me know if this is expected behavior or an actual bug?

title: _.set behavior is too surprising for string array indices

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I just discovered today that `_.set(a, ['b', '0'])` treats the `'0'` as an array index, initializing `a.b` to an empty array if it doesn't exist.

I always assumed it would treat numbers as array indexes, and all strings as object properties, for purposes of initialization, since it's not common to assign an object property using a numeric key, or an array element using a string index...

All the documentation says is

> If a portion of path doesn't exist, it's created. Arrays are created for missing index properties while objects are created for all other missing properties

This is unclear because I thought "index properties" means numbers, not strings that look like numbers.

I've used lodash for many years without realizing this.  One could have code that seems to work properly for a long time until one day a user enters a numeric string.

The documentation should warn that strings which are array indices ([as defined by the ECMAScript spec](https://tc39.es/ecma262/#array-index)) will create arrays at their paths instead of objects.

You might tell me as you have in other threads that I can just use `_.setWith` to create objects for string keys, but since it casts all keys to strings when calling the customizer, I would *only* be able to create objects in that case.

title: Feature: add Array/splitAt function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
## Description

Splits an Array into two parts at the given index with the first resulting array including everything up to but not including the index and the second including everything from the index till the end.

This PR closes #5288

## Usage examples

```js
const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]
const [firstItems, tail] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [1, 2, 3, 4], tail = [5, 6, 7]

const arr = [1, 2, 3]
const [firstItems, tail] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [1, 2, 3], tail =[]

const arr = []
const [firstItems, tail] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [], tail = []
```

**Actual outcome:**

**How to reproduce the issue:**

The second example uses `_.matches` iteratee shorthand, which seems to work.
In this example, both examples should return the same results.

**Versions**

Lodash v4.17.21
MongoDB v4.2.0

title: Deep merge with exception

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello there,
I wonder whether there is the possibility that we can deep merge two objects with some object properties as exceptions?
If I want to explain more, imagine we've got these two objects below:
```
const source = {a: 1, b: {b1: 2, b2: 1}, c: {c1: 1, c2: 3}};
const dest = {b: {b3: 3}, c: {c3: 2, c4: 1}};
```
We want to deeply merge dest object into source using *_.merge(source, dest)* method. But we want to except object property 'b' inside two objects from being deeply merged. Hence the result would become:
```{a: 1, b: {b3: 3}, c: {c1: 1, c2: 3, c3: 2, c4: 1}}```

In my project, I have two objects to be deeply merged, but I need one deep object property inside the two to be excluded from deep merging so that I can completely substitute the dest's deep object property for the source's.

How is the above assignment possible on lodash? Is there any method or syntax defined for this functionality in lodash library?

I would be grateful of any assistance!

title: add extract

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hello 👋. Hope this PR will help many in their software development process.
## What is introduced in this PR?
This PR introduces `extract` function which helps you extract sublists from a given collection and some predicates.
## How is `extract` used?
Let's say we have this array:
```javascript
const documents = [
  { pages: 24,  type: 'ebook',   category: 'finance', ... },
  { pages: 240, type: 'book',    category: 'self development', ... },
  { pages: 41,  type: 'ebook',   category: 'finance', ... },
  { pages: 66,  type: 'ebook',   category: 'it', ... },
  { pages: 2,   type: 'article', category: 'it', ... }
]
```
and we want to extract `finance ebooks`, `self development books` and documents from `it` category.

We can do this with `extract` function I implemented:
```javascript
const [financeEbooks, selfDevelopmentBooks, itDocuments] = extract(
  documents,
  doc => doc.type === 'ebook' && doc.category === 'finance',
  doc => doc.type === 'book' && doc.category === 'self development',
  doc => doc.category === 'it'
)
```
Printing these sublists we obtain:
```javascript
console.log(financeEbooks)
// [ { pages: 24, type: 'ebook', category: 'finance', ... }, { pages: 41, type: 'ebook', category: 'finance', ... }]

console.log(selfDevelopmentBooks)
//  [{ pages: 240, type: 'book', category: 'self development', ... }]

console.log(itDocuments)
//  [{ pages: 66, type: 'ebook', category: 'it', ... }, { pages: 2, type: 'article', category: 'it', ... }]
```
## How would you do this without extract?
```javascript
const financeEbooks = documents.filter(doc => doc.type === 'ebook' && doc.category === 'finance');
const selfDevelopmentBooks = documents.filter(doc => doc.type === 'book' && doc.category === 'self development');
const itDocuments = documents.filter(doc => doc.category === 'it');
```
## Why the addition of extract?
You won't parse the `documents` array three times (or N times generally speaking). You'll only parse it once. Also, you'll declare the sublists in the same place, thus making the code easier to read.

title: groupBy tests not running

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
### Context: 
_I'm having an issue with recent updates to @types/lodash that pertain to groupBy. Before full-on proposing a change in over in that repo, I'm sanity-checking by creating a test case in this repo to represent what we're getting in practice_
<details>
<summary>(the desired test case)</summary>

```js
// test/groupBy.js
  it('should work with a collection of objects', function() {
    var array = [
      { 'group': 'a', 'value': 6.1 },
      { 'group': 'a', 'value': 4.2 },
      { 'group': 'b', 'value': 6.3 },
    ];

    var iteratee = function(value) { return value.group; },
        actual = groupBy(array, iteratee);

    assert.deepStrictEqual(actual.a, [{ 'group': 'a', 'value': 6.1 }, { 'group': 'a', 'value': 4.2 }]);
    assert.deepStrictEqual(actual.b, [{ 'group': 'b', 'value': 6.3 }]);
  });
```
Since that test didn't see to be run, I also tried the following - even though it didn't see to be the right spot for this type of test:
```js
// test/custom-_.iteratee-methods.js
  it('`_.groupBy` should work with objects', function() {
    anIteratee = function(value) { return value.a; };
    assert.deepEqual(_.groupBy(objects, anIteratee), { 0: [{ 'a': 0, 'b': 0 }], 1: [{ 'a': 1, 'b': 0 }, { 'a': 1, 'b': 1 }] });
  });
```

</details>

# Repro Steps:

1. Pull repository
2. Run `npm install` (npm: 7.22.0, node: 16.8.0)
3. Run `npm run test`

# Result:
Out put as follows:
```
> lodash@5.0.0 test
> mocha -r esm test/*.test.js

  add
    √ should add two numbers
    √ should not coerce arguments to numbers
[...]
  functions
    √ should return the function names of an object
    √ should not include inherited functions

  gt
    √ should return `true` if `value` > `other`
    √ should return `false` if `value` is <= `other`
[...]
  xorWith
    √ should work with a `comparator`

  408 passing (3s)
  1 pending
```

# Expected:
I would have expected the groupBy tests (including my newly created 'should work with a collection of objects' case) - with either failure or successes listed for each.

title: Feature: Array/splitAt function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
## Description
Splits an Array into two parts at the given index with the first resulting array including everything up to but not including the index and the second including everything from the index till the end.

E.g.:

```javascript
const arr = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7]
const [firstItems, rest] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [1, 2, 3, 4], rest = [5, 6, 7]

const arr = [1, 2, 3]
const [firstItems, rest] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [1, 2, 3], rest =[]

const arr = []
const [firstItems, rest] = splitAt(arr, 4) // firstItems = [], rest = []
```

## Implementation
```javascript
const splitAt = (arr, index) => [arr.slice(0, index), arr.slice(index)]
```

## Possible feature extension
Split array at multiple indices!
```javascript
const arr = ["H", "e", "l", "l", "o", " ", "W", "o", "r", "l", "d", "!"]
const [arr1, arr2, arr3, arr4] = splitAt(arr, 2, 5, 6) 
// -> arr1 = ["H", "e"], arr2 = ["l", "l", "o"], arr3 = [" ", "W"], arr4 = ["o", "r", "l", "d", "!"]

title: Add an option to ignore undefined in _.concat

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
It would be nice for `_.concat` to have an option of ignoring `undefined` parameters. 

Right now, it is pretty counterintiutive that `_.concat(object.arrayProp1, object.arrayProp2)` will contain an extra `undefined` element at the end when `object.arrayProp2` is `undefined`. 

(The actual problem is, of course, that lodash would have to know if the `undefined` represents an undefined object or an undefined array of objects; even if you decide to keep the current behaviour, documenting it better wouldn't hurt)

title: Crash when using _.merge() with empty immutable collections

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Immutable library in question: https://immutable-js.com/.

In particular, when using immutable Maps or OrderedMaps, if I do a _.merge and one of the OrderedMaps passed into merge is empty, then it crashes spectacularly. The stack-trace also was entirely unhelpful.

Here's a screenshot of the two objects that crash when merged.
![lodash-immutable-crash](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/92947507/138335656-5adc2731-963f-488f-962b-4ae0a3d4a3ab.png)

I think this may be due to how empty immutables have an 'undefined' root node when populated collections have a 'BitmapIndexedNode'. But what do I know.

Anyways, good luck, and thanks for your time! 😄
